Award.AwardTitle: Federal Cyber Service: Scholarship for Service Program at UTD

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The University of Texas at Dallas (UTD) has identified the development of research and teaching programs to "make the nation secure" as one of its six strategic goals and establishes an NSF scholarship for Service (SFS) program. The program is built on strong educational and research foundations in Information Assurance (IA) that UTD has been developing since 2000. The main objectives of the project are to graduate at least 22 highly qualified students in the graduate level IA concentration track program and to provide active mentoring and support to successfully place the graduates in covered federal positions.

A team of faculty, engaged in IA-related research funded by various government agencies, leverages these research activities to enhance the education process of SFS students. The program includes a substantial research experience and students are expected to publish papers in journals and conference proceedings. This integration of research, development and education efforts as well as close collaborations with industry, academia and research labs enable to recruit and graduate students with knowledge of cybersecurity both in theory and practice. The project reduces the current personnel gap in cyber security for the national information infrastructure and it implements a promising approach for recruiting women and minority students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main outcome of this project is the placement of 22students in cyber security jobs with the government. During thepast five years, we recruited 22 students into our SFS program.These students completed their MS in computer science degreewith a focus on cyber security and information assurance. Bythe end of the project, all of these students successfullycompleted their degrees and took qualified government jobsincluding 10 jobs in federal government agencies; 9 jobs withnational labs; 2 with state government agencies; and 1 with afederally funded research and development center.


The SFS program has been instrumental in significantlyimproving the quality and size of our cyber security educationand research activities at UT Dallas. The SFS program enabledthe cyber security team to grow significantly in many aspectsand achieve huge successes. These include the following: (1)recruitment of 5 new faculty in cyber security (3 in CSdepartment and 2 in electrical engineering department); (2)several new cyber security course offerings; (3) a significantincrease in graduate student enrollment in cyber securitycourses (from 184 in 2009-2010 academic year to 399 in2016-2017 academic year); (4) cyber security outreach programsincluding (i) our annual Texas Security Awareness Week (TexSAW)event -a two-day outreach event with several hands on workshopsand a competition in cyber security- for students in otherTexas colleges and universities, (ii) Computer Security Group(CSG) -a campus registered student club- activities aiming atraising awareness of the student body in UT Dallas campus oncyber security and recruiting them into our cyber securityeducation programs, and (iii) high school cyber security summercamps serving over 100 high school students each summer for thepast three summers; a substantial increase in cyber securityresearch —especially in secure cloud computing and malwareanalysis— which has contributed to the new course offerings;and (5) an interdisciplinary graduate level certificate program(offered as a joint program by Computer Science, SystemsEngineering, and School of Management) in cyber securityeducation.

 


Last Modified: 11/29/2016
Modified by: Kamil Sarac
